repnme.cdata!:
Latin America and Caribbean - Conservation
            and Sustainable Use of the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System
            (MBRS) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Conservation and
            Sustainable Use of the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System
            (MBRS) Project for Latin America and Caribbean were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: flexibility is needed in designing
            and allocating budgets to project activities to accommodate
            unanticipated externalities (such as climate change), to
            respond to new opportunities, and to meet changes in client
            needs during implementation. Regional data collection and
            dissemination should be demand-driven to ensure use of
            information and markets to pay for it. Alternative
            livelihoods must be introduced in tandem with restrictions
            on former resource use and closures on new entrants to the
            sector to reduce pressure on targeted resources. Training in
            alternative livelihoods must be accompanied by marketing and
            incubation of new lines of business. The private sector must
            be involved in setting codes of conduct for sustainable
            tourism and in generating investments in greener operations,
            but to engage the industry effectively, regulatory policies
            must be aligned with economic incentives. Implementing
            regional projects to protect Tran's boundary public
            goods is complicated by: (a) processes and institutional
            arrangements in the Bank that are designed primarily for
            single-country operations; (b) differences in client country
            readiness and capacity; and (c) biases that favor national
            interests over shared regional ones. Overcoming these
            barriers requires flexibility in administrative processes,
            innovative financing to access regional financing and
            educating stakeholders about the benefits of a regional
            approach through continuous dialogue, consultation, and outreach.

repnme.cdata!:
Latin America and Caribbean - Conservation
            and Sustainable Use of the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System
            (MBRS) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Conservation and Sustainable Use of
            the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System (MBRS) Project, will
            assist Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, and Mexico in managing
            the MBRS as a shared, regional ecosystem; safeguard
            biodiversity values, and functional integrity; and, create a
            framework for its sustainable use. The components will: 1)
            support immediate improvements in marine, and coastal
            protected areas (MPAs), through planning, management, and
            monitoring efforts, specifically, through the establishment
            of a MPA data-baseline, and monitoring programs; the
            development of management plans for MPAs; supply of basic
            equipment, and infrastructure for MPA planning; and, a
            trans-boundary cooperation in policy, protection, and
            management of MPAs. Capacity building for MPA management
            will include regional training courses/workshops, namely the
            Marine Park and Tourism Resource Development Program, and
            Training Library Development; 2) establish a regional
            environmental monitoring, and information system (EIS), and,
            develop a web-based EIS, as tools to organize, and
            disseminate environmental data on reefs, and ecosystems in
            the MBRS. Targeted research will support field studies, to
            include water quality flows, and develop a hydrodynamic
            surface flow model; 3) promote sustainable fisheries
            management, through institutional strengthening, and
            monitoring, and, facilitate sustainable coastal/marine
            tourism, through policy dialogues, and a cooperative action
            forum; and, 4) develop public awareness campaigns, provide
            formal/informal education, supported by the coordination of
            a regional steering committee, a consultative group, and the
            program coordination unit.

repnme.cdata!:
Latin America and the Caribbean -
            Conservation and Sustainable Use of the Mesoamerican Barrier
            Reef System Project : social assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This Social Assessment (SOA) focuses on
            potential socioeconomic impacts resulting from the
            implementation of the Conservation and Sustainable Use of
            the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System Project in Mexico,
            Belize, Guatemala, and Honduras. It identifies the
            populations who inhabit, and/or enjoy the area's
            ecosystem, in particular the impact of their fishing/tourism
            activities in the barrier reef, to specifically ensure that
            recommendations concerning indigenous/ethnic populations,
            are included in the project design. The first part of the
            SOA describes indigenous/ethnic populations, with a special
            section analyzing the role of women. The second part,
            reviews potential risks, and perceptions of local
            populations regarding recent regional developments.
            Recommendations include supportive indigenous participation
            - Indigenous Development and Participatory Plan - in the
            conservation of the barrier reef ecosystem, focusing on
            specific actions to protect in particular, the livelihoods
            of the poorest, and women. Specific recommendations suggest:
            support income generation alternatives through the promotion
            of ecotourism, and related handicrafts, providing technical
            assistance, and initial subsidies; develop educational and
            vocational training within the formal, and non-formal
            educational system; promote sustainable land uses for
            improved urban, and housing development; improve fishing
            practices within international standards; facilitate
            women's participation through institutional training;
            and, include appropriate indigenous populations' land
            tenure rights within the project's framework.

repnme.cdata!:
Latin America and the Caribbean -
            Sustainable Use of the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System
            (MBRS) Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The main goals of the regional
            Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System (MBRS) project are to
            facilitate enhanced protection of vulnerable and unique
            marine and coastal ecosystems and to assist the countries of
            Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, and Mexico to strengthen and
            coordinate their national efforts for marine ecosystem
            conservation and sustainable use. In order to mitigate
            potentially negative consequences, this environmental
            assessment (EA) suggests the following be considered for the
            construction and operation of the marine protected areas
            infrastructure: Construction will take place during the dry
            season to reduce potential for rain and storm-related
            erosion/sedimentation and contamination. The construction of
            the siting structures should avoid clearing and/or draining
            of mangroves or wetland areas. The EA suggests avoiding
            excavation/dredging or quarrying of coral rocks and sand,
            especially along coastal headlands, reefs, and seagrass
            areas. Construction techniques will include silt barriers
            and berms to control accelerated erosion and sedimentation
            of nearby wetland, riparian or coastal areas. To avoid
            contamination of the surrounding environment with liquid and
            solid wastes caused by the operation of the facilities, a
            solid waste management plan will be in place at the
            initiation of construction. Any oil, grease or fuel should
            be stored in containers and protected from storms.
